Description: Body sherd (joined from two fragments) of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed black with lotus flower in added white outline with added red centres; exterior, from top: cross-hatched pattern frieze; two narrow bands; painted decoration consisting of female figure to right (head in profile with stephane in hair and shoulder with himation remaining).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds of the Grand Style. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in that style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy. It ought to be pointed out, however, that there is no evidence for any filling ornament on the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 99, no. 302.10, pl. XXXII)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 110, p. 113, p. 281, no. 783, pl. 102)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0858) (phase 2)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 211, no. 10)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
